stem: The public health nurse is reviewing the profiles of three attendees at a community health fair. Based on the documented demographics and health histories, match each individual with the most appropriate annual routine screening test.

tabs.title: Client Profiles
tabs.content:
09:00: Ms. Maria Garcia (55y/o female). History of HTN, managed with Lisinopril. No specific symptoms today. Family history: Aunt had breast cancer at age 60. 

10:30: Mr. Robert Jackson (52y/o male). History of Type 2 Diabetes, A1c 7.2%. Social history: 30-year smoking history. Reports no current symptoms. 

11:15: Ms. Susan Lee (42y/o female). History of PCOS and currently taking oral contraceptives. Nonsmoker. Requested information on cervical health screenings.

tabs.title: Health Fair Assessment
tabs.content:
M. Garcia: Visual acuity 20/20 with corrective lenses. 
R. Jackson: Decreased sensation to monofilament test on bilateral plantar surfaces. 
S. Lee: BMI 24. Pelvic exam not performed at health fair.

rationale.correct: Maria Garcia (55) is in the age range (45-54 annual, 55+ biennial or annual) for mammography. Robert Jackson (52) is in the age range for routine colorectal cancer screening (starting at 45). Susan Lee (42) should undergo routine Pap smears (every 3 years for cytology or every 5 for co-testing).
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect pairings overlook the established age-based guidelines from organizations like the USPSTF.

answerBreakdown.rationale: USPSTF recommends screening mammography for women starting at age 40 and definitely by age 50.
Average-risk colorectal screening starts at age 45.
Cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 21 to 65.

clinicalPearls: Screening is for asymptomatic patients. If they have symptoms, it becomes a diagnostic test.
Guidelines for colonoscopy changed from 50 to 45 in recent years.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that a 42-year-old is 'too young' for a Pap smear or that a 52-year-old smoker only needs lung screening and not colon screening.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always prioritize based on general age-related guidelines first unless a higher priority specific risk is mentioned.
